title-group.article-title: Selective Hedging, Information Asymmetry, and Futures Prices*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2006 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: Evidence from hedging practices suggests that firms will hedge only if they expect that unfavorable events will arise. In markets with a significant degree of information asymmetry in which hedgers are oligopolists with superior knowledge concerning supply and demand, such as oil and gas futures, we contend that these companies will selectively hedge price movements, causing sharp price adjustments upon resolution of information asymmetry. Using aggregate analysts’ surprise as a proxy for the degree of information asymmetry, we show that positive aggregate surprises lead to a price decline for futures, which indicates that these firms unload their futures when the outlook is favorable.

fn.p: Research on this paper started when Knill and Minnick were PhD students at the University of Maryland. They would like to thank the faculty there for their useful comments on this paper. Contact the corresponding author, April Knill, ataknill@cob.fsu.edu.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Normative theory in risk management states that companies facing significant exposure to interest rate, exchange rate, or commodity price risk can enhance their value by undertaking appropriate hedge positions using financial derivatives (see Working1953,1962; Culp and Miller1995; Culp2003). The theory emphasizes that the hedgers should systematically hedge their risk by maintaining a hedge position for as long as input or output price volatility affects their net cash flows. Under optimal hedging strategy, profits and losses from hedged assets and derivative positions would offset each other, thus enabling hedgers to reduce the volatility of the net cash flows.

Evidence from hedging data, however, indicates that most firms follow a selective hedging strategy whereby they undertake a hedge position only if they anticipate imminent unfavorable conditions (see Dolde [1993] and Culp [2003] for details). Stulz (1996) argues that while selective hedging, mainly practiced by large corporations, contrasts with theoretically prescribed risk management methods, it can increase corporate value if the hedging firm has a comparative informational advantage. This informational advantage, acquired through its ordinary business activities, allows the firm to predict input and output price movements more accurately than other market participants. Stulz asserts that such specialized information most likely leads to a selective hedging strategy in which expected future price movements influence the proportion of the exposure that is hedged. Among the industries and firms that are more likely to follow a selective hedging strategy, the oil and gas industry seems to be the best candidate. In an oligopolistic industry such as oil and gas, full information revelation can exacerbate competition and drive output prices down (see, e.g., Ziv1993; Einy, Moreno, and Shitovitz2002). This is especially true when member firms become technologically similar; the value of private information about local conditions of supply and demand becomes even more important (see, e.g., Huck, Normann, and Oechssler2000). As such, oligopolies, particularly those with homogeneous technologies such as oil and gas industries, have a tendency to reveal less information.

These information asymmetry and motivated hedging activities have important implications for oil‐ and gas‐related futures prices. If oil and gas companies truly possess better knowledge about the expected price movements than any other market participants, then as O’Hara (2003, 1337) points out, “a nonrevealing equilibrium emerges, and prices do not level the playing field between traders.” However, as the classical Grossman‐Stiglitz (1980) argument and its critique goes, if uninformed traders can make inferences about informed traders’ information through either price movements or other channels, they will adjust their demands for assets accordingly, which will give rise to a fully revealing equilibrium. In the case of the oil and gas industry, however, the uninformed is less likely to be able to infer much about the trading by oil and gas companies. The reason is mainly that there are only a handful of players in the industry, each of whom has only partial information about the overall industry outlook and attempts adamantly to keep that information hidden from competitors and outsiders. As such, even if oil and gas companies follow a selective hedging whereby they purchase futures only when their outlook is unfavorable and unload their futures when their outlook turns favorable, there is no reason to believe that these companies trade in concordance with each other such that their trading activities cause any distinct price movement. Additionally, oil and gas futures markets are deep, liquid, active markets in which informed traders can conceal information effectively. Hence, while the uninformed cannot resolve the information asymmetry from price movements, she can rely on quasi‐private channels, namely analyst forecasts and their error, in predicting oil and gas companies’ performance. Extant evidence shows that analysts often err optimistically in their forecasts of corporate earnings (see, e.g., Butler and Lang1991; Abarbanell and Bushee1997). One main reason for analysts’ persistent optimism is to appease management of the firm under analysis in order to access private information. As Lim (2001) argues, in order for analysts to improve their forecasts, the estimate is biased upward. For analysts to provide more accurate information, they need to maintain a strong relationship with firms; in return, firms demand more favorable recommendations from analysts, which make analysts' forecasts in turn more biased. As Best and Zhang (1995) assert, this inherent trade‐off between accuracy and bias implies that the magnitude of bias is directly related to the degree of information asymmetry. As such, if the aggregate analysts’ forecast error becomes positively (negatively) large, the uninformed can infer that the industry outlook is (un)favorable. Given that major oil and gas companies implement selective hedging strategies, which implies that they will decrease (increase) their futures positions in response to (un)favorable industry outlook, the uninformed then finds that selling (buying) futures would be an optimal strategy.

Here, then, is the question: Do oil and gas companies exploit their information by selectively undertaking hedging positions, which in turn affects futures prices? Assuming that analyst forecast error directly relates to the degree of information asymmetry between oligopolies and the market regarding the local conditions of supply and demand, firms’ inventories, marginal production costs, and so forth, one can hypothesize that aggregate analyst forecast error, or combined earnings surprise (i.e., the difference between analysts’ earnings forecast and actual earnings), for entire oligopolies should proxy the degree to which market participants change their expectation regarding the future economic performance of the industry as a whole. Empirically then, the question becomes, upon announcement of large aggregate positive (negative) earnings surprises, do futures prices fall (rise) significantly?

In this paper, we study the impact of earnings surprises on the oil and gas futures price changes. We examine whether the aggregate earnings surprise affects the changes of oil and gas futures prices both as inputs (crude oil and natural gas futures) and as outputs (gasoline and heating oil futures). Our results indicate that an analyst's forecast does affect futures prices significantly negatively. In line with predictions of a selective hedging theory, our results suggest that oil and gas companies use futures primarily to hedge their spot commodity positions. When the firms’ outlook and, consequently, the prospects of profitability improve, they reduce their hedge positions. When the improved industry outlook is revealed at the earnings announcements, the other market participants react accordingly, leading to fewer long positions in futures and hence depressing the futures prices. Indeed, we find that positive earnings surprises for less integrated companies, such as oil and gas producers and explorers, have more pronounced effects on futures prices. Note that since nonintegrated oil and gas companies (e.g., production and exploration firms) cannot operationally hedge the commodity price risk, they are more likely to use financial contracts such as futures for hedging. With a selective hedging theory (see Stulz1996) whereby firms hedge only the downside risk, in the event of a favorable outlook, nonintegrated firms decrease their usage of futures significantly, hence causing a sharp price decline in futures.

This paper contributes to a number of related literatures. First, we find evidence consistent with selective hedging theory in Stulz (1996). As suggested by Stulz, if firms pursue a selective hedging practice, they will use financial contracts only when their outlook is unfavorable. We find that indeed aggregate positive earnings surprise in the oil and gas industry leads to sell‐offs in the oil and gas futures markets. Oil and gas companies, particularly the nonintegrated firms that use futures as a primary hedging instrument, reduce their usage of futures when their outlook is favorable, leading to a decrease in futures price.

Second, with respect to the literature on futures prices (see, e.g., Pindyck1993; Schwartz1997), it has long been believed that only macroeconomic factors influence the commodity prices (see, e.g., Kalecki1971; Borensztein and Reinhart1994; Reinhart and Wickham1994). This paper also sheds light on whether microeconomic factors such as expected firm performance affect commodity prices. Given the fact that earnings surprises can reflect industry and company outlooks, analyst forecasts can then be used as predictive factors of futures prices.

Finally, with respect to the value of accounting information, this paper can show whether analysts’ forecasts incorporate private information and affect security prices (see, e.g., McNichols and Trueman1994; Barron et al.1998; Barron, Byard, and Kim2002; Chen and Jiang2003). Prior studies find that analysts either overreact or underreact to past public information (e.g., DeBondt and Thaler1985; Abarbanell and Bernard1992; Easterwood and Nutt1999) and analysts’ forecast errors are predictable from past public information (e.g., Abarbanell and Bushee1997) and show consistent optimistic bias (e.g., Butler and Lang1991).

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: inSection II, we describe the sample, elaborate empirical methodology, and discuss our findings. We then summarize and conclude the paper inSection III.

Note that in a model of daily futures price movements, analyst forecasts’ error is an unforeseen event. Hence, from an econometric perspective, we need to define a version of model(3)that incorporates these events efficiently (see Flannery and Protopapadakis2002). Our main conjecture as stated before is that analyst forecast error can approximate the peripheral conditions. As such, in lieu of Z
t , we will use analysts’ forecast error, or “earnings surprise,” as a proxy for Z
t . Our basic empirical model then is a simple regression equation as follows:
where ERROR t is a measure of aggregate earnings surprise for the industry. We follow Best and Zhang (1995) in defining the measures of information asymmetry. The authors use firm‐level earnings surprises and a dummy variable for earnings upgrades to measure the level of information asymmetry of each firm. Best and Zhang indicate that “given the importance of earnings information in security selection and performance evaluation, it is expected that predictions of corporate earnings should provide significant information to the market” (1510). They rank firms on the basis of the absolute value of their analysts’ forecast error and posit that firms with low forecast error have little residual information asymmetry after the earnings are released. Conversely, they suggest that firms with high forecast error represent firms for which information asymmetry remains significant even after earnings forecasts are released. Inasmuch as we are examining the information in an earnings surprise caused by an unanticipated price drop (increase) due to (un)favorable firm outlook, the sign of the surprise is of import. Consequently, we use the analyst forecast error instead of the absolute value of the same. Best and Zhang use an indicator of firm type as measured by change in the analyst forecast. Firms are categorized into three groups for which earnings forecasts have been upgraded, unchanged, or downgraded from the previous period. Best and Zhang argue that this metric represents the unanticipated change in the market’s expectation about the firm’s prospects. To gauge aggregate earnings surprise for the industry, we use the mean, median, and total sum of the earnings surprises of all firms in the industry. Additionally, we use the total sum of earnings upgrades in the industry as an alternative measure of aggregate earnings surprise. We first construct a dummy variable indicating if earnings forecasts have been upgraded, unchanged, or downgraded. We then sum across all member firms and use the total sum as a proxy for information asymmetry.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Data
sec.p: For futures data we use the daily nearest crude oil, natural gas, heating oil, and unleaded gasoline futures contracts traded on NYMEX. All data are obtained from R&C Research Group courtesy of NYMEX. Our sample period for crude oil, heating oil, and unleaded gas runs from November 11, 1988, through December 31, 2001, and consists of 3,280 observations. Natural gas observations stem from the period from June 1, 1990, through December 31, 2001, and consist of 2,883 observations.

For companies in the Fortune 500 oil and gas industry, listed intable 1, we obtain the analysts’ earnings forecasts from the First Call database for the period 1990–2001. We then measure the analysts’ forecast errors or earnings surprises by computing the difference between the actual reported earnings and the average forecasts. Our sample includes 25 companies, of which only six are integrated oil and gas companies (seetable 1). Except for these integrated companies, the rest specialize either in marketing‐refining or in exploration‐production. We later use firm characteristics, that is, whether they are integrated or specialized, as distinguishing features in our analysis. It appears that the integrated firms are the largest oil and gas companies, with an average size of $76.25 billion; the marketing‐refining companies are second largest, at $56.36 billion; and exploration‐production companies are an average size of $5.50 billion. Interestingly, with regard to profitability, the price‐to‐book ratios of integrated oil and gas companies are quite comparable to those of other companies. The returns on equity for integrated firms, marketing‐refining firms, and exploration‐production firms are 13.98, 12.06, and 13.97, respectively. The price‐to‐book ratios for integrated firms, marketing‐refining firms, and exploration‐production firms are 1.89, 1.70, and 2.01, respectively. While operational efficiency of these firms seems to be comparable, a closer look at their dividend yield suggests that exploration‐production firms may have a significantly lower cash reserve. This suggests that these companies use a relatively large portion of slack for reinvestment, which leaves them more vulnerable to oil and gas price fluctuations. Hence, we contend that, compared to integrated and marketing‐refining companies, exploration‐production firms are more likely to rely on financial contracts such as futures to hedge their risk. This implies that earnings surprises of nonintegrated firms then should have a much more pronounced impact on futures prices. We later examine whether earnings surprises of different sectors of the oil and gas industry indeed affect futures prices differently. Table 1

The distribution of earnings announcements in our sample period, as seen in figures1and2, demonstrates that these announcements are quite dispersedly spread over the period.Figure 1shows the frequency of earnings announcements for all the firms in our sample, andfigure 2shows the daily earnings announcements for different segments of the industry. Both figures indicate that earnings announcements are not clustered in a particular day, although most are reported around the end of each quarter.1Among all industry segments, the exploration‐production firms have the most number of reports. This is expected given the larger number of these firms in our sample that have more frequent announcements. Heuristically, both figures also indicate that occasionally announcements from different segments coincide with each other. If earnings surprises in different sectors of the industry contain different information, then this suggests that aggregating all surprises may distort our analysis. Having said that, given a reasonably dispersed nature of earnings announcements in our sample and the fact that our industry segments are noninclusive, we expect the impact of coincidental reporting to be minimal. Fig. 1.—
Frequency of daily earnings announcements: This graph shows total number of earnings announcements per day (bold black bars) for the period January 1, 1990, to December 31, 2001. The crude oil price during the same period is also plotted (gray line). As is evident, the earnings announcements are spread over the period, and except for occasional coincidental reporting, oil and gas companies report their earnings at quite different dates.
Fig. 2.—
Frequency of earnings announcements for each industry group. This graph shows the number of daily earnings announcements for each of three industry segments: integrated, refiners‐marketers, and explorers‐producers of the oil and gas industry for the period January 1, 1990, to December 31, 2001.

fn.p: In excess of 80% of all firms report their earnings within a week of the quarter end.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Univariate Results
sec.p:
The univariate analysis, shown intable 2, demonstrates that mostly positive (negative) earnings surprises are followed by a sharp fall (rise) in futures prices. Significant differences between futures price movements following large earnings surprises and futures price movements in other days suggest that market participants do incorporate newly released information about futures of the oil and gas industry. Moreover, the magnitude of the information asymmetry between management of firms in the oil and gas industry and other futures markets participants is significant enough to give rise to consistent large price movements following public releases of information. Interestingly, the price movements on days preceding the earnings announcement do not suggest any information leakage to the market, leaving earnings surprises as the only mechanism with which the uninformed can resolve or reduce the degree of information asymmetry. This lack of preannouncement reaction also indicates that our sample, which contains a time series of announcements, is widely dispersed across the period.2Large price reactions over longer preannouncement windows confirm that the postannouncement reactions due to earnings surprises are less likely to be confounded by any clustering in our sample. Consistent with the argument found in Grossman and Stiglitz (1980), subsequent to earnings announcements, uninformed traders react accordingly and adjust their portfolio holdings to reflect the futures trading of the informed (the oil and gas companies). Additionally, our results show that the information content of positive and negative surprises is different. After negative surprise announcements, heating oil, unleaded gasoline, natural gas, and crude oil futures prices rise by 0.67%, 0.30%, 0.21%, and 0.16%, respectively. After positive surprise announcements, heating oil, crude oil, and natural gas futures prices decline by 0.47%, 0.33%, and 0.33%, respectively, and unleaded gasoline prices rise by 0.05%. The negative association between futures prices and earnings surprises is clear evidence of the selective hedging of oil and gas companies. If a decrease in information asymmetry regarding the firm’s prospects would not affect the firm’s hedging practices, the announcement should have no impact on input and output futures prices. However, if the hedging strategy is closely tied to how the firm perceives its future profits, then positive announcements should lead to a significant decrease in using futures and potentially an unloading of the existing positions, which in turn pushes futures prices down.

Second, our results indicate that output and input futures respond asymmetrically to earnings announcements. In contrast to input futures, output futures prices increase more after a negative earnings surprise than they drop following a positive earnings surprise. One possible reason for the observed asymmetric response is the market structure of the oil and gas futures. Input markets are dominated by a handful of oil‐ and gas‐producing corporate or sovereign entities. Since oil and gas companies each have only partial knowledge about conditions of the industry, they cannot react exclusively on the basis of their knowledge alone. Upon the earnings announcements revelation of their competitors, these companies can verify whether their estimates of the state of industry bear any truth. Aggregate surprises then work as certification for each company’s forecast, and hence when the outlook of the industry is truly favorable, oil and gas companies decrease their futures holdings, pushing prices down. When an aggregate negative surprise verifies an unfavorable outlook for the industry, all these companies need to do is to adjust their limited hedge positions to make accommodations for any unforeseen shocks. On the other hand, the output markets include legions of other companies that use oil and gas products as input in their operations. In the event of negative news, not only oil and gas companies but also all other participants will rush to hedge the price hikes and hence push futures prices excessively high. In anticipation of an unfavorable industry outlook, all firms, oil and gas as well as others, purchase futures to protect their cash flows from excess volatility. On the eve of a favorable outlook, only selective hedgers, namely oil and gas companies, reduce their futures positions, causing prices to drop less severely.

An asymmetric response of input and output futures can also be attributed to operational management of the oil and gas companies. Borenstein and Shepard (2002) suggest that costly production and inventory adjustments cause a lagged change in gasoline prices following crude oil price shocks. Borenstein and Shepard additionally find that gasoline prices respond to oil price increases at a more rapid pace than decreases. This asymmetric response to input price changes implies that since oil and gas companies more rapidly pass on any crude oil and natural gas futures price hikes, there will be little or no time left for other output (unleaded gasoline and heating oil) market participants to adjust their portfolios. As a result, the other market participants are forced to react swiftly to unfavorable earnings announcements.

fn.p: We thank the referee for bringing this point to our attention.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Multivariate Results
sec.p:
Simple present‐value model.—Our univariate results clearly indicate that information asymmetry, as measured by the analyst forecast error, affects futures prices of both inputs and outputs. Our results further show that oil and gas companies’ seemingly selective hedging leads to an asymmetric response to positive and negative earnings surprises. We estimate model(4)for input (crude oil and natural gas) and output (unleaded gasoline and heating oil) futures to test for any confounding effects. Our multivariate results indicate that aggregate analysts’ forecast error does affect futures prices. Though not significant for all contracts, the impact is by and large pronouncedly negative, suggesting that upon resolution of information asymmetry, market participants actively adjust their portfolio in response to newly estimated risk, hence affecting the futures prices. As is shown in tables3and4, all measures of information asymmetry affect all futures prices negatively except natural gas futures. A percentage increase in the mean or median earnings surprise of all oil and gas companies leads, respectively, to a 1.74% and 1.81% decrease in crude oil futures prices, a 3.65% and 3.78% decrease in unleaded gasoline futures prices, and a 3.85% and 4.11% decrease in heating oil futures prices. The negative association between earnings surprise and futures price changes further indicates that market participants presume that oil and gas companies selectively hedge risk. Consequently, in the event of positive (negative) news, they react accordingly, decreasing (increasing) their futures positions, causing futures prices to drop (rise) upon announcements. Table 3

Further examination suggests that the impact of the favorable industry outlook on natural gas futures is neither significant nor pronounced. As mean and median earnings surprises rise, the natural gas prices remain intact. We suspect that since not all firms in the industry specialize in natural gas processing, an overall outlook for the entire industry may be less relevant for players in the natural gas market. We also find that neither the sum of analysts’ forecast errors nor the sum of analysts’ upgrades has significant explanatory power. Since a summation does not discriminate between different analysts with varying degrees of predictive accuracy, these metrics can be confounded. We discuss this issue at length in later subsections.

Alternative model specification.—Previous studies have documented strong volatility persistence and autocorrelation effects in futures prices (see, e.g., Liew and Brooks1998; Fong and See2002). Liew and Brooks find that palm oil futures have strong volatility persistence (i.e., generalized autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity [GARCH]) effects. Fong and See find that in addition to GARCH effects, crude oil futures reveal a strong regime‐switching pattern around major volatility‐inducing geopolitical events.

Even in our case, despite rather modest performance of our earlier models, further examination shows that our naive models do reveal a significant degree of autocorrelation and heteroscedasticity. Our analysis shows that adding at least two lagged prices along with a simple GARCH(1, 1) structure for the variance of futures prices could improve the model performance. Additionally, extant literature documents distinct day‐of‐the‐month and month‐of‐the‐year effects in futures (see, e.g., Khaksari and Bubnys1992; Fong and See2002), which can coincidentally account for some contemporaneous effects of earnings announcements.

As such, we need to modify model(4)to account for these well‐documented price‐volatility patterns to control for unforeseen events. We first introduce longer lagged prices to account for autocorrelation. We then add a volatility persistence equation, a GARCH (1, 1) model. To control for other unforeseen events, we include two‐ and three‐day lagged futures prices as well as weekday and year end dummies. This is incorporated in the following equation:

The results, in tables5and6, confirm our earlier findings that, notwithstanding the choice of proxy measurement for information asymmetry, positive aggregate earnings surprise decreases both input (except for natural gas) and output futures prices significantly. A percentage increase in the mean or median earnings surprise of all oil and gas companies leads, respectively, to a 1.31% and 1.40% decrease in crude oil futures prices, a 3.51% and 3.89% decrease in unleaded gasoline futures prices, and a 3.77% and 4.03% decrease in heating oil futures prices. We take comfort in that the magnitude of coefficients and their statistical significance in our newly specified models are quite comparable to those of earlier models, indicating that although our GARCH models perform better, the impact of analysts’ forecast error is not materially affected by model specification. The results again show that even after we control for strong volatility persistence effects and considerable autocorrelations, the analysts’ forecast error has a significantly pronounced effect on futures prices. The negative association between earnings surprises and futures prices further confirms our earlier findings that markets assume that oil and gas companies employ a selective hedging strategy, which in turn links their oil and gas hedging by futures strongly to their economic outlook. Motivated by actions of oil and gas companies, market participants, including some of the oil and gas companies, then rebalance their futures portfolios upon earnings announcements, affecting futures prices depending on the industry outlook. Even after controlling for other possible confounding factors, we conclude that aggregated positive (negative) surprises lead to a fall (rise) in oil‐ and gas‐related futures prices. Because of the predictable selective hedging practices of oil and gas companies, markets react upon resolution of information asymmetry about the direction of these likely hedge positions and adjust prices to reflect their newly assessed upside or downside price risk.

Selective hedging and information asymmetry.—In the previous subsections, we argue that our findings indicate that oil and gas companies employ selective hedging. We argue that if oil and gas companies use futures for hedging only when the overall industry outlook is unfavorable, they should reduce their oil and gas futures holdings when the outlook is favorable. Since an aggregate positive earnings surprise indicates an overall favorable outlook, such surprises should be followed by sharp declines in futures prices simply because the hedgers sell their positions and push the price downward. If our conjecture is accurate, then earnings surprises of those firms that are more prone to use financial contracts as opposed to operational mechanisms to reduce volatility will have a larger impact on futures price movements. Thus firms that do not control complete flow of inputs (crude oil and natural gas from the wells) and outputs (gasoline at the pump) such as exploration‐production firms and, perhaps to a lesser extent, marketing‐refining firms must use futures contracts extensively to reduce price volatility and to hedge price risk. Indeed, an aggregate positive earnings surprise will imply that these firms are more likely to react and unload their futures more rapidly, which in turn motivates market participants to follow suit and unload their futures, hence pushing the price down more significantly.

To test this contention, we use model(5), which includes weekday and year end dummies as proxies of other unforeseen factors and controls for heteroscedasticity and autocorrelation. We add to it the aggregate earnings surprises of three sectors of the industry: integrated, refining‐marketing, and production‐exploration companies. This is incorporated in the following equation:

The results in tables7and8indicate that only integrated and explorers’ earnings surprises affect the futures prices. For a 1% increase in the positive surprise in the average earnings of integrated oil companies, the crude oil, unleaded gasoline, and heating oil futures prices drop by 1.05%, 3.94%, and 3.61%, respectively. For a 1% increase in the positive surprise in the average earnings of oil and gas producers and exploration companies, the crude oil, unleaded gasoline, and heating oil futures prices drop by 1.56%, 4.02%, and 3.12%, respectively. Earnings surprises of marketers and refiners appear to have no statistically significant impact on oil‐ and gas‐related futures prices. Since producers, explorers, and integrated firms bear the risk of carrying inventories and smoothing production, it makes sense that their economic outlook affects their hedging strategy more pronouncedly than marketers and refiners that pass the price shocks to the end consumer directly. Sectorwide earnings surprises send a strong signal as to what direction these large players in the futures market will move, causing other participants to follow suit and adjust their futures holdings accordingly. Large positive surprises initiate a selling frenzy for fear of less demand by oil and gas producers and explorers for futures, pushing the futures prices downward. Table 7

Similarly to our univariate and multivariate results, we find that the impact of the earnings surprises of oil and gas producers, explorers, and integrated firms on output futures prices is more pronounced. This further confirms the findings of Borenstein and Shepard (2002) that output futures prices respond faster to an increase in fundamental commodity prices because oil companies, particularly ones with considerable market power, can manage their production and inventories in accordance with changes in the market place, affecting end output prices. That is, when oil and gas companies face an unfavorable outlook, they rapidly pass the oil and gas price hikes to the end consumer, causing output prices such as unleaded gasoline and heating oil prices to jump. This in turn leaves little time for other market participants to adjust their positions and hence create a much larger selling frenzy, leading to greater price movements. Our results also indicate that earnings news about refiners and marketers has no valuable information regarding the sector outlook simply because these companies can respond to input price shocks directly, that is, by raising gasoline prices at the pump.

sec.label: E.
sec.title: Robustness Analysis
sec.p: While our preceding analyses clearly indicate that earnings surprises affect futures prices, we provide sensitivity analysis based on potential measurement errors inherent in defining “earnings surprise.” Since analysts pursue other objectives (e.g., career concerns that lead to herding and simply mimicking others) than simply predicting a firm’s earnings, which can affect their assessment of risks and the magnitude of information asymmetry, it stands to reason that an erroneous surprise measurement may reflect more than just information asymmetry. For instance, Hong, Kubik, and Solomon (2000) and Hong and Kubik (2003) point out that the career concerns and herding among analysts can give rise to consistent biases in their forecasts. They suggest that to control for such biases, the analyst performance in predicting earnings compared to other analysts in the same security and industry should be incorporated into the forecast errors.

Following their procedure, we first rank analysts according to the precision of their forecast of the next period’s earnings. We then assign a score between zero and 100 (zero reflecting no precision and 100 reflecting perfect accuracy) and subsequently redefine our aggregate earnings surprise as the score‐weighted average of each analyst’s forecast error. As shown intable 9, the new measure of earnings surprise has a significantly negative impact on crude oil, unleaded gasoline, and heating oil futures. For every percentage positive surprise in the score‐weighted average earnings of oil and gas companies, the crude oil, unleaded gasoline, and heating oil futures prices drop by 2.44%, 3.63%, and 3.59%, respectively. As in earlier models, our measure of information asymmetry does not appear to affect natural gas futures prices significantly, perhaps because most firms in our sample do not produce, market, or sell natural gas products. Results with the newly defined measure of information asymmetry confirm our main hypothesis that analysts’ forecast error has information regarding the outlook of the oil and gas industry, which in turn, along with selective hedging practices of major oil and gas players, has a pertinent impact in predicting oil and gas futures prices. As Lim (2001) points out, the information content in all forecasts for the quarter end earnings may contain valuable information. A potential problem with our estimates is that we used the latest reported estimates (as discussed in O’Brien [1987]) instead of taking all of the estimates into account. In order to ensure that the results are not affected by the choice of estimates, we also run the analysis using the methodology suggested in Lim (2001). Lim imposes a three‐month recency rule. He uses as the definition of the consensus forecast bias for each company in a quarter the median of all brokers’ latest unrevised estimates of the company’s earnings quarter, submitted no more than three months prior to end of the quarter, minus actual earnings from Compustat and expressed as a percentage of adjusted stock price. This was motivated by Brown (1991), who shows that earnings forecast accuracy can be improved by discarding stale estimates. Following Lim, we use the most recent unrevised estimate of each broker, ensuring that all are within three months of the earnings announcement. We then take the median of these estimates across brokers for each actual date. Using the median, we compute the surprise as the difference between the median estimate and actual earnings. The results, shown intable 10, confirm our earlier findings. Positive aggregate earnings surprise decreases both input and output futures prices. Although the results are not as strong as they are using the last estimate, the results provide valuable insight about the process of information revelation that occurs through the estimate revisions. If market participants revise their beliefs about the industry outlook as new analyst revisions are released, then it stands to reason that only the latest surprise, not the historical earnings surprises, affects futures prices, reflecting the unforeseen portion of embedded information. The surprise calculated with inclusion of only the most recent estimates is a more accurate measure of the information, which influences futures prices since updated estimates are public information and perceptions based on the estimates would be updated along with the revisions along all interested parties to act accordingly along the way. Only the information revealed upon the announcement of actual earnings, which is based on the most recent earnings, affects futures prices. To further examine whether indeed market participants incorporate updated information in their assessment of the industry outlook, we reestimate our models using all available earnings forecasts for every quarter. Not surprisingly, these new estimates have less economic and statistical significance than the ones produced using the last three months of earnings forecasts. The difference between the results utilizing all estimates and only the most recent ones simply demonstrates the information discovery that ensues throughout the quarter.Table 10is included for the sake of completeness only. Finally, given the size differences of the companies in our sample, it is important to control for the impact that firm size might have on earnings surprises. In the above analysis, we assume that all firms are equally weighted. To ensure that this assumption does not drive our results, we weight the surprises by different size measures, specifically, assets and revenues. We use these two measures as weights, because larger sales may give more incentive to hedge, and larger firms may use selective hedging more often. We do not use market value since price fluctuations may add additional noise to the weights. Using the weighted surprises, we rerun model(4)using the ordinary least squares (OLS) method and models(5)and(6)using the GARCH method. The results, shown intable 11, confirm our earlier findings. Both the magnitude of coefficients and their statistical significance in our newly specified models are consistent with our earlier findings. Interestingly, however, the magnitudes of coefficients on the weighted surprises are smaller than those on nonweighted surprises, suggesting that perhaps smaller firms have more informative earning surprises. Another explanation is that firm size, as measured by sales or assets, proxies the industry segments. As noted earlier, our findings show that earnings surprises of smaller firms such as oil and gas explorers and producers have larger, more significant impacts on futures prices. Hence, to examine whether size in our analysis merely proxies for industry segments, we reestimate models(7)and(8)using weighted surprises. Our results, shown intable 12, indicate that even after we control for firm characteristics and industry segment effects, our findings are robust and that weighted surprises have a relatively smaller impact on futures prices. This further confirms our earlier conjecture that since smaller firms cannot smooth unwarranted shocks though operational hedging, they are more prone to use selective hedging as a means of shielding their income from downside risk. In other words, although intuitively one expects large firms to be more prone to use selective hedging, since in an oligopoly larger firms enjoy economies of scale and scope, they are less likely to use exclusively financial contracts to hedge risk. sec.label: III.
sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Recent surveys indicate that large corporations, such as oil and gas companies, consistently implement selective hedging strategies whereby the firm acquires offsetting derivative positions only when its risk manager foresees unfavorable events imminently. This, however, implies that markets for these derivatives suffer from a large degree of information asymmetry because while oil and gas companies knowingly adjust their positions, the other participants will be left in the dark to assess in what directions the prices will move. In such a case, the analysts’ forecasts of the oil and gas companies and their errors in predicting the outlook of the industry prove extremely informative. Since analysts have access to oil and gas executives and should be able to incorporate their private knowledge about the immediate and long‐run prospects of these firms in their estimates of earnings, their aggregate error in predicting industry earnings can gauge the extent of information asymmetry present and help market participants to react effectively.

We test our central hypothesis by examining whether analyst forecast error as a measure of information asymmetry affects futures prices or not. If oil and gas companies use futures contracts to selectively hedge risk, they hedge only the downside risk. When industry outlook is good (bad), they will scale down (up) on their futures usage, hence pushing futures prices higher (lower). We find that, indeed, aggregate earnings surprises negatively affect the futures prices, confirming our conjecture that in “good times” oil and gas companies will not use as many futures contracts. The impact of this on futures prices implies that microeconomic factors such as expected firm performance affect commodity prices and that analyst estimation does have implications on futures prices.
